item.title: Judge Extends Block on Trump Officials Slashing Funds to Democratic States
item.description: The decision kept at bay a freeze of nearly $10 billion in child care and other social service funds destined for Minnesota and four other Democratic-led states.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim and Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: A preschool program in Manhattan. The Trump administration had sought to choke off funds for child care programs in New York and four other states.

item.title: Hegseth Says Defense Department Will Cut Ties With Harvard
item.description: Mr. Hegseth’s order appeared to target his alma mater, Harvard’s Kennedy School for public policy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

item.title: Super Bowl Visitors Find San Francisco Better Than Its Apocalyptic Image
item.description: Problems with homelessness and open-air drug use have been widely broadcast, but many visitors this week said they found the city surprisingly pleasant.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Ferry Building is a popular spot for visitors walking along San Francisco Bay on the Embarcadero.

item.title: Psychiatrist Says Kennedy Was ‘Not Accurate’ in Discussing His Keto Studies
item.description: Dr. Christopher M. Palmer said in an interview that the keto diet, while promising, did not “cure” schizophrenia as the health secretary had claimed.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Wednesday, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said that “we now know that the things that you eat are driving mental illness in this country,” and that a doctor at Harvard had “cured schizophrenia using keto diets.”

item.title: Colorado Funeral Home Director Is Sentenced to 40 Years in Corpse Abuse Case
item.description: “I deserve every word you have said and every day that I will sit in prison,” Jon Hallford said in court on Friday. Investigators found nearly 200 decomposing bodies stored improperly.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Rylee Kirk
item.category: Return to Nature Funeral Home (HallfordHomes LLC)
item.media:credit: Parker Seibold/The Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Local authorities prepare to set up tents outside the Return to Nature Funeral Home where more than 100 bodies were discovered to have been improperly stored, in Penrose, Colo., in 2023.

item.title: Republican Chairman of Homeland Security Spending Panel to Exit Congress
item.description: Representative Mark Amodei of Nevada added his name to the growing list of Republicans planning to give up their seats as their party faces losses that could cost them the House.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Mark Amodei, Republican of Nevada, has demonstrated a willingness to criticize the Trump administration’s immigration operations.

item.title: F.B.I. Investigates Links to Biological Labs in Las Vegas and California
item.description: The Las Vegas lab had vials of a “reddish liquid,” the police said. The California lab, uncovered in 2023, had materials “possibly associated with infectious diseases,” officials said.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin

item.title: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore on 2028, Democrats’ Problems and His Favorite Crab Cake
item.description: The Maryland governor discussed Trump, the country’s divisions and his workout routine.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Wes Moore of Maryland

item.title: Cuban Deportees Who Were Transferred to Guantánamo Sent Back to U.S.
item.description: Dozens of men appear to be caught up in a political standoff between the Trump administration and Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Lauren Wood/The Natchez Democrat, via Associated Press
item.media:description: All but one of the men were being held on Friday at the Adams County Correctional Center in Natchez, Miss.

item.title: Moderates Pitch Tough-on-Crime Message for Democrats Amid Immigration Talks
item.description: A polling memo circulated among centrist senators urged Democrats to talk tougher on crime, an issue where they lag Republicans, while noting an opportunity for the party to appeal to voters with criticism of ICE.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, Democrat of Nevada, has been urging her colleagues to strengthen their credibility on the issue of crime and public safety.

item.title: Trump Is Hosting Governors at the White House, but Only Republicans
item.description: The president’s decision to exclude Democratic governors from an annual meeting later this month breaks a longstanding tradition.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado has clashed with President Trump in recent months over Mr. Polis’s refusal to pardon Tina Peters, a former county clerk.

item.title: Bard College President Leon Botstein Was Close With Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: Bard College’s president, Leon Botstein, said his school needed cash. But a rare watch and a Caribbean visit show how his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein sometimes veered into the personal.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Botstein has been leading Bard College since 1975. He says his connections with Jeffrey Epstein were focused on raising money for the school.

item.title: In Talks, Trump Won’t Allow Iran to Have Any Enriched Uranium
item.description: Can the two sides get past Iran’s claim that it has a “right” to enrich uranium?
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers at a uranium conversion facility in Isfahan, Iran, in 2005. Analysts say Iran’s position on enrichment reflects the country’s intense pride in a nuclear program that has become a symbol of Iranian independence.

item.title: Nancy Guthrie’s Disappearance Rekindles Kidnapping Fears
item.description: High-profile abductions, like those of Patty Hearst and J. Paul Getty III, have captured the nation’s attention, but experts say kidnappings by strangers are exceedingly rare.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: National Center for Missing and Exploited Children
item.media:credit: Jan Sonnenmair/Getty Images
item.media:description: The disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, the mother of the “Today” anchor Savannah Guthrie, is the latest case of its kind to capture the nation’s attention, reviving fears about kidnappings.

item.title: Nancy Guthrie’s Abduction Set Off a Storm. This Sheriff Is Riding It Out.
item.description: Sheriff Chris Nanos is surrounded by chaos but is trying to keep his cool as the search for a celebrity news anchor’s mother grinds on.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault and Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble/Reuters
item.media:description: Sheriff Chris Nanos is contending with the F.B.I. director, a horde of reporters and the forces of celebrity. And then there’s the investigation itself.

item.title: Libyan Man Is Arrested in Deaths of 4 Americans in 2012 Benghazi Attack
item.description: The man, Zubayar al-Bakoush, is the third suspect apprehended for the 2012 attack on U.S. facilities that killed four Americans.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Esam Omran Al-Fetori/Reuters
item.media:description: The United States consulate in Benghazi, Libya, was attacked in September 2012.

item.title: Judge Allows Release of Evidence From Border Patrol Shooting
item.description: A Border Patrol agent shot Marimar Martinez five times. Video from the October incident in Chicago could now be released as early as Monday.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz and Robert Chiarito
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prosecutors charged Marimar Martinez with assaulting federal officers, but later dropped the case.

item.title: A Pro-Israel Group’s Move Backfires as Gaza Tensions Flare in Midterms
item.description: A surprising twist in a New Jersey primary race showed how questions about Israel continue to roil American politics in unpredictable ways.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski and Brian Fraser for The New York Times

item.title: California Sues a Children’s Hospital to Maintain Transgender Health Care
item.description: As the Trump administration pushes to end such care, this is the first time a state has sued a hospital to preserve it, legal experts say.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We will not allow Rady Children’s to violate its obligations to its patients and the State,” Rob Bonta, California’s attorney general, said.

item.title: Officials Pressed Schumer to Help Name Penn Station and Dulles Airport for Trump
item.description: Administration officials told the top Senate Democrat the president would release frozen funding for the Gateway project if the transportation hubs were renamed for him.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A construction site for the Gateway mass transit project in Manhattan on Thursday.

item.title: Harvard Proposes Capping As at 20 Percent to Curb Grade Inflation
item.description: A recent report found that a majority of grades given out at Harvard were A’s. Professors will vote on a proposal to limit the number to around 20 percent.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Justice Dept. Pursues Many Officer Assault Cases in Minnesota as Misdemeanors
item.description: It is a pattern that has played out in other cities where the administration has conducted immigration surges and taken a muscular stance against those accused of impeding federal officers.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters confronting federal agents in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: U.S. Seeks to Expedite Deportation of 5-Year-Old Liam Conejo Ramos
item.description: Liam was detained last month near Minneapolis during an immigration enforcement operation in which his father was also taken into custody by federal agents.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: U.S. Rep. Joaquin Castro, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Adrian Conejo Arias and his son, Liam Conejo Ramos, in San Antonio after being released from an immigration detention center in Dilley, Texas.

item.title: Latest U.S. Boat Strike Kills 2 in Pacific
item.description: The operation was authorized by the Marine general who took command of military operations in Latin America and the Caribbean earlier in the day.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Francis L. Donovan on Capitol Hill last month. He is the commander of U.S. military operations in Latin America and the Caribbean.

item.title: Trump Deletes Racist Video Portraying the Obamas as Apes
item.description: The video clip that President Trump posted in a late-night flurry of social media activity caused an unusually strong and public outcry from members of his own party.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Isabella Kwai and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Authorities Investigate a New Message in Nancy Guthrie Kidnapping Case
item.description: The F.BI. and local law enforcement gave no details about the note, which came on the sixth day of the search for Ms. Guthrie, the mother of the “Today” host Savannah Guthrie.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara/Associated Press
item.media:description: A sign of solidarity from neighbors at Nancy Guthrie’s home in Tucson.

item.title: As Minnesota Reels Amid Immigration Crackdown, a Sheriff Agonizes Over Her Role
item.description: Sheriff Dawanna Witt of Hennepin County says she thinks she could help end the crackdown by allowing some measure of cooperation with ICE. She also knows that could cost her re-election.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheriff Dawanna S. Witt of Hennepin County was sworn into office in 2023, becoming the first woman and the first person of color to hold the office.

item.title: These New Englanders Won’t be Rooting for the Patriots in the Super Bowl
item.description: When the New England Patriots take the field on Sunday, a collective sigh will rise from the willful few who live in the region but root for other teams.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Carmen Mandato/Getty Images; Scott Taetsch, via Getty Images; Mike Roemer, via Associated Press

item.title: ‘Gang Stuff’ and ‘Illicit Trysts’: How Epstein Sought Leverage With the Wealthy
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein drafted letters to men like the retail billionaire Leslie Wexner in which he hinted at shared secrets.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Fred Squillante/Columbus Dispatch, via USA Today Network
item.media:description: Leslie Wexner, the retail billionaire behind Victoria’s Secret, was one of Jeffrey Epstein’s most important clients.

item.title: What to Know About Minnesota’s Immigration Policies Amid Federal Crackdown
item.description: The Trump administration has criticized state and local “sanctuary” policies during its Minnesota immigration crackdown. The reality on the ground is complicated.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clashed with Minnesotans while attempting to stop a resident as part of Operation Metro Surge in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: How the Black Panthers’ Playbook Helped Minneapolis Activists Fight Trump
item.description: The monitoring of federal agents by activists has been at the heart of the opposition to the Trump administration’s raids. The tactic has a long history.
item.dc:creator: Charles Homans
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists have tried to block often-bellicose federal agents, which has led to frequent street confrontations.

item.title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Steps Onto a Wider Stage
item.description: The progressive lawmaker is taking a larger role in Democratic politics, supporting moderate candidates and helping drive the party’s economic message. Now she is planning a major trip abroad.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning, Reid J. Epstein and Leo Dominguez and McKinnon de Kuyper
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
